body:
### Problem

The `mksession` command is used to save a "session"[1], which includes, but isn't limited to, the buffers that are currently open, so that they can be restored by the `-S` option at a later time. The problem is that the *order* of these buffers in your session is not actually preserved by `mksession` or honored by `nvim -S`. For example, suppose the buffers in your session looks as follows:

| file1.py | file2.py | file3.rs
| :--- | :--- | :---

You use the `mksession` command to save it and then you exit, but when you use `nvim -S` to restore your session, you typically end up with a different buffer ordering; e.g.:

| file3.rs | file1.py | file2.py
| :--- | :--- | :---

(The above is just one possibility and should not be interpreted as implying that it would predictably end up that way.)

I recall seeing an issue where some comments explained why changing buffer orderings *after* they had been created wasn't possible or desirable[2], which, AFAIK, means that, to change buffer ordering, the only available option is for the user to close the buffers and manually re-open them in the desired order. This isn't a great user experience, IMO, especially when you work with lots of files at a time. (Note: This is about helping users keep their workspaces organized, not about trying to find open buffers.)

I don't know if this is due to `mksession` not *preserving* buffer order when it creates the `Session.vim` file in the first place or `nvim -S` not *respecting* these data when reading the `Session.vim` file to restore the user session.

The `sessionoptions` in the docs don't seem(?) to have a value that would enable, control, and/or imply the proposed behavior. Supposing, *arguendo*, that this is feasible, perhaps this behavior could either: be implied by an existing value, or be handled by a new one?

For completeness' sake I'm using the `snap` package of `nvim`, version `0.9.4`, so, if this behavior is already in some kind of roadmap for a future release, I'd appreciate being pointed to it.

Thanks.

**PS:** [This issue](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/28297) may or may not be related to this.

[1]: I may be using some terms, like "session", here a bit loosely, but I hope what I mean is clear from context.

[2]: ~May've been related to buffer number/IDs and plugins, IIRC. Either way, the relevant point is that users can't reorder buffers, not the underlying cause.~ See [this issue](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/7558).

### Expected behavior

The expected behavior would be for the buffer ordering in sessions restored by `nvim -S` to match the order they had when the `mksession` command was used to save it. For example, the buffer ordering below should be preserved/respected when saving/restoring sessions with `mksession`/`nvim -S` respectively:

| file1.py | file2.py | file3.rs
| :--- | :--- | :---
